awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Invisible Floods on the Mississippi River Floodplain: Unravelling the Causes of Urban Flooding in a Community-Centered Approach to Geomorphology
awd_abstract_narration:
Stretching for over 80 miles along the Illinois bank of the Mississippi River, the area of Mississippi River Floodplain known as the American Bottom is home to over 130,000 people who depend on infrastructure that controls and curtails flooding. Although the Mississippi River is the most the significant threat to floodplain communities in the American Bottom, a system of floodplain channels has triggered some of the most widespread and damaging incidents of flooding. In some cases, substantial infilling with sediment and woody material has caused these channels to literally pour into some of the most economically vulnerable communities in the US. In this EAGER proposal, the investigators will apply a new model in the practice of geomorphology, in which scientists and community members collaborate in inquiry and data collection. They will focus their initial efforts in the community of Centreville, Illinois, where the impacts of flooding have been the most damaging. They will work directly with the community to better constrain the causes and impacts of severe flooding, and to broaden their engagement with communities of the Greater St. Louis region, they are partnering with Harris-Stowe State University to offer four summer internships to rising seniors of the university. Their goal is to build meaningful and empowering undergraduate research experiences for underrepresented minorities by designing those experiences around civic engagement and environmental science.

The investigators aim to demonstrate how community-centered research that is applied to managed and inhabited landscapes can, at the same time, lead to novel and impactful insights into landscape evolution. In their case, the focus is on floodplain channels of the American Bottom. Floodplain channels have been a focus of research in geomorphology for some time, but these previous efforts have largely focused on floodplain channels whose very forms are produced and controlled by lowland rivers. Floodplain channels whose forms and function are largely independent of lowland rivers, but instead are a product of upland drainages, are much less understood. The investigators will provide the first geomorphological assessment of the floodplain channels of the American Bottom, including both natural and modified reaches. By integrating field surveys, sediment coring, and numerical experiments the investigators will: 1) calculate sediment supply rates from bluff drainages into floodplain channels; 2) determine how and why sediment transport capacity varies along floodplain channels; and 3) identify flood risks associated with channel infilling for Centreville.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Centreville, IL has suffered pervasive flooding for decades. However, to date, no action has been taken towards mitigating these hazards and their associated economic and social impacts on the community. Regular flooding in Centreville has persisted, nearly daily in some neighborhoods, for almost two decades without mitigation or intervention. Spring and summer floods have required public evacuations (last covered by popular press in 2015), and persistent flooding in some neighborhoods has waterlogged homes to such an extent that county officials have condemned some residences. The frequent and pervasive flooding in the Centreville community, paired with the lack of any mitigation efforts due to the lack of adequate "return on investments", represents a clear example of environmental injustice in Centreville.

A key need articulated by residents during our first meeting was for the comprehensive documentation of the conditions that drive flooding in the neighborhood, as well as documentation of flood frequency and flood extent. While residents have relayed their personal experiences of flooding to state agencies, due to limited resources and lack of infrastructure, no concrete or systematic documentation of flood hazards was available.  Guided by community needs and resident experiences, in 2020 we installed ten time-lapse cameras throughout the community to continuously monitor flood extent. Installed cameras captured one photo and a 5 second video every 30 minutes at each location. We also installed two pressure transducers to monitor water levels every five minutes in a small channel that runs through the community and drains the nearby bluffs. Qualitative analysis of these ground-based time lapse images clearly demonstrates that Centreville residents experience frequent, severe flooding, even under moderate precipitation conditions. Correlation of individual ponding events with daily precipitation records suggests a precipitation threshold of between 0.5-1 inches/day to initiate severe surface ponding across the community, though moderate ponding was often observed below this threshold. 

We also developed and calibrated a hydrologic model using the Hydrologic Engineering Center-River Analysis System (HEC-RAS) developed by US Army Corps of Engineers to estimate flood extent under a range of precipitation scenarios. We demonstrate that inundation is widespread even under moderate precipitation rates across the community, consistent with findings from field-monitoring efforts.   We also show that the precipitation threshold identified from images was consistent with rapid increases in inundation as predicted by the calibrated flood model at the camera locations. We also find that our calibrated flood model reflects areas where water will pond due to topography, but that existing FEMA flood models of the 1% flood do not capture the flooding that we model or observed from the field-monitoring efforts.

While these results were consistent with residents lived experiences, they help to demonstrate these experiences and the severity of flooding experienced by the community through direct observations and modeling. Community-engaged cooperation with data collection efforts guided the project scope and field-based efforts significantly, allow our team to focus areas of the community where flooding was most pervasive and damaging to resident?s properties and day-to-day life.  Results of this work support mitigation efforts sought by residents and community partners.  As part of these efforts, we cooperated with the community partners working to support these efforts to seek environmental remediation and relief for residents from nuisance flooding. We advocate for a community-engaged model for future studies of urban monitoring and modeling. Additionally, as part of this project, we provided two, eight week research internships to students from Harris Stowe State University, a St. Louis HBCU.
